subject: RE: [junit] Re: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?

messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: kentbeck@... [mailto:kentbeck@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, July 18, 2001 12:04 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Re: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
>
>
> Except:
> assertTrue(true)
> assertTrue(collection.size() == 2)
> assertTrue(collection.elementAt(2) = foobar)
>
> would all score the same, while the value of each assertion is
> radically different. What could such a metric tell me that I don't
> already know?
>
> Kent

The above examples all indicate that you checked some condition, although
some are more meaningful than others. Your point is well taken that one
assert may be more heavily laden with information than others.

So it really comes down to information content. If you have to report the
effectiveness of your tests, typically to justify your efforts (and whys of
this are subject to debate elsewhere), then you want meaningful,
information-rich metrics that are easy/transparent to gather.

My point is that there is more information content in your average assert
count than test case count. It's not very high in content but still higher.
Some asserts imply more than others, as Kent's examples above show.

So assert is not a great metric but is certainly easy to derive, so why not
use it? It also promotes use of asserts, which is a good thing. Sometimes
people will create tests that have too few assertions and think they are
done if they run without exceptions. Reporting an assertion count in results
would make people aware of their lack of assertions. Of course you can
always get crazy and do derived metrics such as assert to LOC ratios, etc.
but I think that may be beyond the spirit of XP/JUnit.

Mike

>
> --- In junit@y..., "Michael Silverstein" <msilverstein@s...> wrote:
> > I don't have a strong opinion one way or another but I've seen a
> number of
> > appends that held up some number of tests as a metric of the
> effectiveness
> > of their unit testing. It would strike me that a more meaningful
> metric
> > would be the number of asserts, since that indicates how many
> conditions
> > were checked for correctness. So it is true that a unit test passes
> or it
> > doesn't and if it doesn't, you fix it and move on. However, if
> someone is
> > going to tout metrics, they should at least pick one that is as
> meaningful
> > as possible.
